sections.title: Overview
sections.content: India is a vast South Asian country known for its diverse cultures, languages, religions, and landscapes. It is the world’s largest democracy and one of the fastest-growing economies.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: New Delhi is the capital of India, serving as its political center, while Mumbai is the largest city and financial hub.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency is the Indian rupee (INR).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: India has no national language but recognizes Hindi and English as official languages, alongside 21 other scheduled languages.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Indian cuisine is incredibly diverse, with popular dishes including biryani, butter chicken, dosa, samosas, and masala chai.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: India’s geography ranges from the Himalayas in the north to coastal plains in the south, with deserts, fertile river valleys, and tropical forests.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Indian culture is shaped by Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam, Sikhism, and Christianity. Festivals, music, dance, cinema, and literature are central to its identity.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism highlights include the Taj Mahal, Jaipur’s palaces, Kerala’s backwaters, Goa’s beaches, and the Himalayan mountains.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: India is the birthplace of chess, yoga, and Ayurveda, traditions that have spread worldwide.

history.event: The Indus Valley Civilization flourished, one of the world’s earliest urban cultures.
The Vedic period began, laying the foundations of Hindu philosophy and society.
The Maurya Empire was founded by Chandragupta Maurya, later flourishing under Ashoka.
The Gupta Empire ushered in a golden age of science, art, and literature.
Arab traders and conquerors introduced Islam to India.
The Delhi Sultanate was established, ruling much of northern India.
Babur founded the Mughal Empire, which became a major power in South Asia.
The Battle of Plassey marked the beginning of British dominance in India.
The Indian Rebellion of 1857 challenged British rule but was suppressed.
India gained independence from Britain, leading to the partition of India and Pakistan.
India adopted its constitution and became a republic.
India supported Bangladesh’s independence during the Bangladesh Liberation War.
Economic liberalization reforms opened India to global markets, sparking rapid growth.
India launched the Mars Orbiter Mission (Mangalyaan), becoming the first Asian nation to reach Mars orbit.
